title: Entertainment One sees losses widen as its shareholders prepare to vote on Habro's takeover
text:
Peppa Pig owner Entertainment One has reported widening losses in its first quarter amid falling sales in its TV and film division, rising debt and acquisition costs.

The trading update comes just a week before the expected completion of the £3.3billion takeover by American toy giant Hasbro, the maker of Monopoly and My Little Pony.

Shares in Entertainment One fell by 0.3 per cent to £5.61 on Friday, only slightly above Habro's offer of £5.60 per share.

They were worth less than £4 before the takeover approach, but rose to a record £5.89 in the wake of the offer in August.

Canada-based Entertainment One said fewer scripted programmes hit sales

Canada-based Entertainment One said fewer scripted programmes hit sales, which fell 7 per cent to £173.1million in the three months to the end of June compared to the same period last year.

Pre-tax losses rose almost seven-fold to £43.9million after one-off charges worth £28million in part associated to its acquisition of Audio Network in April.

Hasbro's bid is expected to win support from Entertainment One's shareholders at their annual general meeting on 17 October.

The deal needs regulatory approval and the backing of investors holding at least two-thirds of the Canada-based, UK-listed firm's shares.

Last week, it emerged that Entertainment One had hired Georgeson, an influential shareholder lobbying firm known for its work in takeovers or battles with activist investors.

Hasbro said that the move would 'dramatically enhance' its story-telling capabilities.

Shares in Entertainment One fell by 0.3 per cent to £5.61 in morning trading, only slightly above Habro's offer of £5.60 per share

Updating investors on trading in the first quarter, Entertainment One said the timing of releases hit sale.

However, it said the scripted television market remained 'vibrant', with new series in the pipeline including original horror series Red Rose for BBC1 and a pilot for Anna K, a modern retelling of Tolstoy's Anna Karenina set in New York City.

Meanwhile its music revenues got a boost from the acquisition of Audio Network for £178million in April.

'Its first quarter trading doesn't make for great viewing,' said Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell.

'While the takeover was always likely to be approved, today's update will sharpen shareholders minds with many likely feeling a bid came just in time.'

'The hope now must be that there are no issues over the regulatory approval of the transaction.'
